name: Learning from Failure
summary: The practice of extracting lessons and insights from failures to improve future performance.
explanation: Learning from failure is the practice of extracting lessons, insights, and improvements from failures to enhance future performance. While often discussed, genuine learning from failure is rarer than assumed - many people fail without learning. Effective learning requires: honest assessment (not defensive attribution), systematic analysis (not just emotional processing), and applied lessons (not just understanding). Barriers to learning include: ego protection (blaming external factors), cognitive dissonance (avoiding uncomfortable insights), and lack of feedback (not knowing what went wrong). The learning process involves: documenting what happened, analyzing contributing factors, identifying actionable lessons, and implementing changes. Organizations can promote learning through: psychological safety, blameless post-mortems, and institutional memory systems. Individual practices include: failure journals, personal retrospectives, and mentor debriefs. For knowledge workers, learning from failure means: treating every significant failure as a learning opportunity, being honest about personal contributions to failures, and implementing changes rather than just understanding them.
